awd_titl_txt: Bioinorganic Chemistry of Catechols: Siderophores, Adhesive Proteins and Biomimetic Analogs
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Alison Butler from the University of California, Santa Barbara to investigate the properties of compounds called catechol-siderophores that are produced by bacteria.  The compounds are similar to the molecules that make it possible for mussels to cling tenaciously to rocks in the ocean.  This research examines the reasons for the recently discovered properties that allow mussels to cling even to slick, wet surfaces.  This project may provide an understanding of the biological phenomenon and may lead to the design of compounds that can adhere even under water.  The role of catechol-siderophores in iron acquisition by bacteria is also investigated.  This research project provides broad multidisciplinary training for graduate and undergraduate students.  Professor Butler and her students are involved in outreach workshops including, CAMP (California Alliance for Minority Participation), an NSF-funded program supporting minority undergraduate students in science, technology, engineering and mathematics fields, and SCOPE (Science as a Career Outreach Project Experiment), a program for graduate students to talk in local high schools about undergraduate and graduate education and the value of the sciences as a career choice.

The research is investigates siderophores and analogs containing both catechol and amine functional groups that mimic the strong wet adhesive properties of mussel foot proteins. The overall goals of the first part of this proposal are to elucidate the synergistic role of the catechol and the amine functionalities in displacing the interfacial hydration layer that develops on mineral surfaces leading to robust adhesion. The approach is to design and investigate the surface adhesive properties of new biomimetic compounds through direct force measurements with a surface forces apparatus. The goals of the second part of this research are to investigate the biosynthesis, uptake, and iron(III) release mechanisms of acylated tetra L-serine, and tris-catechol siderophores through investigation of key fatty acid coenzyme A ligases, outer membrane receptor proteins, and esterases identified in the genomes of the producing bacteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Catechols play many roles in biology, of which iron(III) coordination by microbial siderophores and aqueous surface adhesion to minerals by mussel foot proteins (mfps) are significant to the research in this grant. The discovery of expanded versions of enterobactin (e.g., amphi-enterobactins, and cyclic trichrysobactin, CTC; Figure 1) punctuates the significance of the tri-Ser lactone scaffold appended by catechol, cationic amines and fatty acids to microbial iron acquisition.  The discovery of significant adhesion to a mineral surface in aqueous solution, by catechol- and cationic amine-containing siderophores (e.g., CTC) and structural analogs of CTC marked the inspiration to investigate the molecular foundation of the wet adhesive properties of mussel foot proteins. In terms of the intellectual merit of this research, the goals of this project were a) to decipher important elements of wet adhesion through a biomimetic platform inspired by tris-catechol-amine siderophores, and b) to predict and identify new members of the expanding class of tri-Ser catechol siderophores, as well as other siderophores.

Mussel-inspired adhesives containing paired catechol and cationic functionalities are a promising class of materials for biomedical applications, but few studies address the molecular adhesion mechanism(s) of these materials. Adhesion measurements conducted with a surface forces apparatus was carried out on a series of Tren-based catechol-cation compounds, by increasing the catechol-cation spacing though incorporation of non-binding Gly residues (Figure 1, Top). The adhesion of these molecules to muscovite mica in an aqueous electrolyte solution demonstrates direct intramolecular adjacency of catechol and cationic functionalities is not necessary for synergistic binding, although increasing the catechol-cation spacing, results in decreased adhesion, which was attributed to a decrease in the density of catechol functionalities. A mechanism for catechol-cation synergy was proposed based on electrostatically driven adsorption and subsequent binding of catechol functionalities.

Through genome mining we investigated new oligo-L-Ser, tris catechol siderophores which are expanded versions of enterobactin (Figure 1).  The amphi-enterobactin biosynthetic gene cluster was identified in many Vibrio species.  The fapA gene (and it homologs), which encodes an outer membrane receptor protein, was found to be essential for the uptake of Fe(III)-amphi-Ent, as well as the exogenous siderophore enterobactin. We discovered biosynthetic gene clusters for new cationic-amine containing triscatechol siderophores and isolated and characterized, frederksenibactin with L-Lys and ruckerbactin with L-Arg; both of which resemble the wet adhesive catechol-amine compounds, but are also diastereomeric with known siderophores trichrysobactin with D-Lys and trivanchrobactin with D-Arg (Figure 1). Moreover, through genome mining, we discovered the origin of the stereospecific hydroxylation of aspartic acid in b-OH aspartyl-containing peptidic siderophores.

For broader impacts within the scientific community, we have elucidated factors promoting robust adhesion by catechol-amine siderophore analogs in aqueous environments, which is important to the development of new wet adhesive materials and understanding properties of mussel foot proteins.  For impact in training and outreach, the grant period provided multidisciplinary training to the six graduate students and four undergraduates in my laboratory carrying out research on this project. During this grant period, three students obtained their PhD degrees. Graduate student involvement in outreach activities over the grant period included NSF CAMP (California Alliance for Minority Participation).  One graduate student co-led the UCSB Institute for Scientist and Engineer Educators (ISEE) outreach program, preparing early career scientists for higher education teaching roles and one led a yearly workshop on effective teaching for new chemistry graduate student TAs.  


Last Modified: 02/01/2022
Modified by: Alison Butler

Image
  • Tren-based catechol-cation compounds synthesized for wet adhesive investigations and diastereomerically related tris catechol-cation siderophores discovered by microbial genome mining.
    Alison Butler
